newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares end floor trade on a closing high.
newsitem.headline: German shares end floor trade on a closing high.

text.p: Germany's blue-chip DAX index hit new record high in bourse trade on Thursday and ended on a new closing high. Dealers said 4,500 points was within reach, even though volumes are lower than in previous days.
The 4,500-point level would count as yet another landmark in the current bull-run. Technical analysts say that the current upward trend line is still intact.
The DAX index ended at 4,438.93 points, up 17.21 points or 0.39 percent.
The September DAX future earlier came to within a whisker of 4,500 when it hit 4,498 points.
"We were a bit shaky at the beginning. Volumes are a little lower than in recent days, but I'm confident that we can reach 4,500 points at some stage over the day," a Frankfurt broker said.
Another successful run on Wall Street overnight underpinned early gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Index closing around one percent higher at 8,254.89 points.

The dollar was slightly weaker at around 1.83 marks, but remained stable and provided support. "I can't think of anything original to say anymore about the dollar and the German share market," one Frankfurt broker said.
Among the main corporate news were industrial giant Daimler-Benz's first-half figures, which came in at around expectations.
Operating profit in the first half rose to 1.849 billion marks compared to 827 million marks in the same period a year previously.

Shares in Daimler fell after the figures and ended the session down 4.50 marks at 154.80 marks, which dealers said was mostly due to profit-taking as the share had risen around nine percent already during the week.
Focus over the session was again on the financial sector. Among losers were banks Vereinsbank down two marks at 101 marks and Hypo-Bank down 1.07 marks at 76.53 marks.

Insurer Allianz AG Holding was down 9.50 marks at 1,470 marks. Earlier Vereinsbank detailed the terms of its planned merger with its fellow Bavarian bank Hypo-Bank. It said its offer to exchange one share in Allianz for six shares in Hypo-Bank would run from August 4 to September 10.

The utility sector was in favour as part of a sector rotation, dealers said, with the sector in need of some catch-up having trailed other sectors, notably the banks and the chemical companies, in the recent record-breaking run.
Veba AG ended up 3.70 marks at 106.90 marks, Viag AG was up 3.50 marks at 793.00 marks and RWE AG was up 70 pfennigs at 81.80 marks.
